If there is hope for 
      an end to the terrorist violence carried out by radical Muslims, it begins 
      with people like Nasir Abas. Abas, you will learn in our lead story, is 
      trying to convert Muslims to the true, peaceful path of Islam. Abas once 
      lived for the jihad, helping to run a terrorist training school in the 
      jungles of Southeast Asia, until the new dictum from Osama bin 
      Laden to kill civilians shocked his sensibilities. It was too late to take 
      back what he had already done. He realized that he had trained the 
      terrorists who had detonated two bombs that killed 202 people on 
      Bali in 2002. But he vowed to make up for 
      his mistakes and at no small risk to himself, has testified against agents 
      of his former al Qaeda-affiliated group, Jemaah Islamiya, and speaks 
      regularly to Islamic students to urge them to reject radicalism and 
      violence. "We need to educate 
      people. We need to give more explanation, about what is right, what 
      is wrong…this is my new jihad," Nasir tells correspondent Bob 
      Simon.
 
Watch an excerpt of Simon's 
      report.
 
 
Talk radio has no shortage of 
      hosts who have declared jihad against illegal immigrants, but now 
      television has one too, and an unlikely one at that. In our second 
      story, you'll meet the transformed Lou Dobbs, CNN anchor who once reported 
      business news with all its elite corporations and profits, now reborn as a 
      populist pundit standing up for the common man and, oftentimes, railing 
      against a common enemy: illegal immigrants. Correspondent Lesley Stahl is 
      surprised to learn that Dobbs, though he never called for their 
      deportation, believes the U.S. could deport all the 
      estimated 12 million illegal immigrants if it wanted to. "Because this is 
      the United 
      States. I think this country can do 
      anything it sets its mind to," says Dobbs.
 
Watch an excerpt of Stahl's 
      report.
 
 
Seventy-four year-old Teri 
      Horton, an ex-truck driver, has set her mind to something and she won't 
      let go. She has turned down $2 million for a painting she paid $5 
      for. She’s not crazy, just convinced – and there’s a fingerprint on the 
      back that matches one from the artist’s studio – that the big, drippy 
      painting is a Jackson Pollock. Our third story pits this feisty, 
      plainspoken woman against the connoisseurs of the art world who won’t 
      accept that this thrift store purchase is really an abstract impressionist 
      masterpiece maybe worth $50 million. CNN’s Anderson Cooper 
      reports.
 
Watch Cooper's reporter's 
      notebook.
 
 
These stories and Andy 
      Rooney's headaches over headlines in the newspaper, this Sunday, May 6, on 
      60 Minutes at 7 p.m. ET/PT.
